awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Microwave flow cytometer for real-time monitoring of fermentation
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is in providing new techniques for brewers, distillers, biofuel producers, and biopharmaceutical companies to increase yield, reduce cost and minimize potential losses.  Microwave flow cytometry (microFC) technology is promising to accurately measure cell density, monitor cell viability, and detect microorganism contaminations at high throughput and in real time without the use of expensive reagents. The long term and continuous monitoring process also requires minimal human intervention. Thus, the technology is promising to provide its users precise and instantaneous information for process control and optimization as well as early contamination detection.  It can help improve yield and product quality while save water, energy and manpower, while promoting discoveries of new biomanufacturing processes and new products.

This I-Corps project will explore the market potential for microwave flow cytometry (microFC) technology by investigating the needs of companies that use biological cells to manufacture products. microFC is based on novel microwave interferometer technology, which includes novel tuning mechanisms to cover broadband frequency ranges for specificity and allows for high sensitivity sensing. Employed in the interferometer system is a microwave sensor with embedded microfluidics that transport individual cells through the sensor, measuring multiple parameters of yeast cells and bacteria including cell density (cells/mL), volume, and physiological state (viability and bedding cells). The measurements are reagent-free and noninvasive. microFC's are expected to enable low cost and easy-to-use online cell monitoring, which will fill an instrumentation gap in both industry and academia.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, a total of 102 interviews were conducted at a variety of companies in and related to the beverage and fuel alcohol industries, including breweries, distilleries, fuel ethanol plants, yeast suppliers, and others. Most of the interviews conducted were at breweries, distilleries, and ethanol plants, with totals of- 27, 43, and 12 respectively, with the remaining 20 interviews being in related industries, such as yeast producers and microbiology analytics companies.

It is confirmed that conducting cell counts is a crucial aspect of the production process for fuel ethanol plants and medium to large breweries and distilleries. However, the needs of all alcohol producers are not the same. While cell counts are important in any production process, the methods used at breweries versus distilleries and fuel ethanol plants are different. Breweries have a much "cleaner" fermentation in that the sugars being converted to alcohol, called wort, are filtered prior to fermentation so there is little debris from grains in fermentation tanks, which makes the cell counting process significantly easier. Distilleries and ethanol fuel plants, on the other hand, do not have a need to filter out grains prior to fermentation, and as such have a significant amount of debris in their tanks, making cell counts much more difficult. Nevertheless, manual count is a common practice even though it is slow and tedious. An online, real-time and accurate cell monitoring technique is needed, but not yet available.  It is also confirmed that early detection of microorganism contaminations in all the targeted industries are important, especially in ethanol plants. Currently, selective culturing or molecular methods, e.g. polymerase chain reaction (PCR), are used.  But there is a lack of online techniques.  The proposed technique could help address the technology gap where a significant market is available.

The microwave technology will also provide a new method for customers in research communities to study fundamental biology and discover new medicine. It will promote discoveries of new bioethanol processes, which can save water and energy by increasing bioethanol yield and productivity.  Additionally, the project provided opportunities to train young entrepreneurs, such as the entrepreneur leads (Els) of the project, and young engineers, such as the graduate students who are working on the technology development. The project will further facilitate technology transfer from basic research to commercial products.
